name: Hypoglossal Nerve Stimulation for the Treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea
description: This policy outlines the medical necessity and limitations for FDA-approved hypoglossal nerve stimulation for the treatment of moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea in adult patients who meet specific clinical criteria, including age, BMI, AHI, and demonstrate CPAP failure or intolerance.

restrictions.condition: Patient is 22 years of age or older
Patient's Body Mass Index (BMI) is less than 35 kg/m2
A polysomnography (PSG) was performed within 24 months of the first consultation for HGNS implant
Patient has predominantly obstructive events, defined as central and mixed apneas less than 25% of the total AHI
Apnea-Hypopnea Index (AHI) is between 15 and 65 events per hour
Patient has documented CPAP failure (AHI greater than 15 despite CPAP usage)
Patient has documented CPAP intolerance (less than 4 hours per night) and shared decision making with a sleep expert is documented
Patient has documented CPAP intolerance (less than 5 nights per week) and shared decision making with a sleep expert is documented
Patient has documented CPAP intolerance (CPAP device has been returned) and shared decision making with a sleep expert is documented
Absence of complete concentric collapse at the soft palate level, confirmed by drug-induced sleep endoscopy (DISE) procedure
No other anatomical findings that would compromise performance of the device
Tonsil size is not 3 or 4 per standardized tonsillar hypertrophy grading scale (i.e., size less than 3)
The hypoglossal nerve neurostimulation system is FDA-approved
Patient does not have an implantable device that could experience unintended interaction with the HGNS implant system
Absence of neuromuscular disease
Absence of hypoglossal-nerve palsy
Absence of severe restrictive or obstructive pulmonary disease
Absence of moderate-to-severe pulmonary arterial hypertension
Absence of severe valvular heart disease
Patient does not have New York Heart Association (NYHA) class III or IV heart failure
Absence of myocardial infarction within the past 6 months
Absence of severe cardiac arrhythmias within the past 6 months
Absence of persistent uncontrolled hypertension despite medication use
Absence of active, serious mental illness that reduces the ability to carry out Activities of Daily Living (ADLs) and would interfere with the patient's ability to operate the HNS
Absence of coexisting nonrespiratory sleep disorders that would confound functional sleep assessment
Patient is not pregnant and does not plan to become pregnant
Patient requiring MRI does not have HGNS device model 3024 (MRI incompatible)
Patient is able to or has necessary assistance to operate the HGNS sleep remote
Absence of any condition or procedure that has compromised neurological control of the upper airway
Inserting provider for Drug Induced Sleep Endoscopy (DISE) is certified by the FDA-approved manufacturer’s second opinion service of validation
Provider certification for DISE requires at least 80% agreement in validation studies
Provider certification for DISE requires validation via at least 15 consecutive studies
Physician performing HGNS insertion is a qualified physician (MD or DO) who is board certified or board eligible otolaryngologist
Physician performing HGNS insertion has completed an AMA or AOA certified residency program in otolaryngology
Surgeon implanting the system has received classroom instruction by an FDA-approved device manufacturer on device implant techniques and cadaver training
Sleep physician or sleep technician has received classroom instruction on how to titrate the device and hands-on operation
Provider maintains documentation of training completion to a satisfactory level
Sleep physician performing evaluation, referral, and post-implant evaluation is board eligible or certified
Sleep technicians meet the qualifications outlined in LCD L34040
Sleep studies are performed in an accredited sleep facility as stated in LCD L34040
